div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,

THURSDAY, JUNE 13, 1907.

div.head: EGYPT AND A PROTECTORATE.
div.p: In his message on the subject of a protectorate for Egypt, referred to in our special cables on the 7th inst., the Paris correspondent of the "Daily Telegraphs" saus : -

"No importance, so far as I can gather, is attached here to an article which recently appeared in an Egyptian newspaper arguing that the time has come for England to substi- tute a protectorate for the occupation, as the journal in question is not regarded as suffi- ciently influential for its own opinion to carry any particular weight, and the sentiment thus expressed is not supposed to have derived inspiration from any outside quarter. In point of fact, as I learn, absolutely no hint on the subject of the possible development of the occupation into a protectorate has been receiv-

ed from London in Paris, where, moreover, such a contingency has never formed a topic of official speculation. As every politician is aware, in the convention which set the seal to the entente cordiale, France recognised Eng- land's position in Egypt, but neither at that date nor since was there, or has there been, any allusion to a protectorate, for which, indeed, the consent of France, as well as the approval of other Powers, would be necessary as an intial proceeding. The Sultan, as Suze- rain of Egypt, would, in the natural order of things, have to be applied t first, and then would come the turn of the States concerned, with the capitulations, the mixed tribunals, and so forth. Even if eventual consent all round was obtained, it would be a lengthy business, as France found after she had settled herself in Tunis, although she made light of the Sultan's claims to authority over the Regency. Such, at least, is the impression which I have de- rived from conversations with competent French judges of these matters. For the rest, these authorities are not inclined to lay any special stress on whatever symptoms of inde- pendence may be evinced, either by the Khedive or by the Nationalist, party although they do point to the fact that the British force of occupation is now reduced to the very simplest expression, perhaps not wuite as prudent a state of htings as optimists on your side of the Channel appear to imagine. In short, there seems to be no sign whatever of any contem- plated change in Egnland's police towards Egypt. If the present system has its draw- backs, it is argued that no change could be introduced without long and laborious ne- gotiations, which would have the effect of reopening the whole question of England's tenure of authority, and might not, after all, be particularly successful in the end. Such bold initiative, at any rate, is certainly not expected from the present Government."
The Berlin correspondent of the "Telegraph" writing on this question on the same day states :

"Replies which I have received to informal inquiries in official circles suggest that the German Foreign Office has not yet adopted any definite attitude to the proposal put forward in the native Egyptian Press that Great Britain should take advantage of the situation created by the retirement of Lord Cromer to regularise her positon in the Valley of the Nile. At the same tim ean inclination was perceptible to assume that if the formal political relationships and designations at Cairo were modified so as to be mor ein con- formity with the actualities of the situation, no unreasonable or vexatious obstacles would be raised from this quarter. It was pointed out that Prince Bulow had in respect to Egypt followed the principles of Bismarck, though, as might have been added, the Iorn Chan- cellor's motives had ceased to be applicable, and tha tnothing had recently been said or done which indicated anu change in this de- partment of his policy. As recently as November last, in hi sspeech in reply to the now famous Bassermann interpellation, Prince Bulow, appealing to the precedent set by his illus- trious predecessor, and followed by himself, complained that Germany had been suspected of intriguing in Egypt, though precisely there sh ehad shown a most accomodation spirit to the controlling Power. His words may be repeated :

Prince Bismarck usd to say, "We are Austrian in Servia, Russian in Bulgaria, and English in Egypt." Since the days of Bismarck, too, we have always recognised the favourable effects of the English co-administrationin the land of the Nile, and have never placed stones in the way of England in Egypt, even when we might have had formal righ to do so. I mean the proclamation of th eKhedviail Edict of 1904, to which we gave our agreement without further ado.

The beneficent influence of British rule at Cairo was further admitted in the frankest and most generous terms by the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Herr von Muhlberg at the great banquet to the journalists last week. He spoke of our work in Egypt as "one of the greatest triumphs" of our Colonial policy, and continued : "In a positively amazing manner has that eminent statesman, Lord Cromer, contrived to rouse the land of the Pharaohs to new life, to new energy."

It seems fairly safe to regard these utterances as characterising th eofficial standpoint on the matter in question. Moreover, as far as can be judged, they represent also the view of the great German public. When Lord Cromer's retirement was announced, the papers were filled with ungrudging and unqualified eulogies of his work, though at that particular moment there was a general disposition to look at all policies of British origin with anything but a kindly eye. There is, hiwever, another side to the question, and a highly-placed offi- cial, who has made a careful study of the question on the spot, was seriously inclined to doub tthe advisability of any considerable modification of the gubernatorial fictions that have grown up at Cairo. In his opinion the native population will always be easier to manage with the maintenance of nominal inde- pendance than under a system in which there would be no institution to veil the reality of an alien government, which has never been gladly borne even by the meekest of races, and however beneficent its operation might have been.

div.head: Mineral Waters.
div.p: We remind our readers that Spathis' are the best mineral aters in Egypt. [ADVT.]

div.head: Fire at Helouan.
div.p: A small fire took place yesterday at Helouan, when a barn stocked with grain caught fire, causing damage estimated at about 30.

div.head: Savoy Palace Hotel.
div.p: The Administration of the Savoy Palace Hotel at Alexandria requests us to announce that it has decided to close the hotel from June 15 to October 1. [ADVT.]

div.head: Sale of Land.
div.p: A property of 200 feddans of agricultural land situated at Arkashaudeh, near Kalioub, and belongin gto Mr. Kassem Bey Amin, a member of the native Court of Appeal, has been acquired by Ahmed Effendi Radi, of Saleh el Gouaber for a sum of L.E. 40,000.

div.head: Egyptian Army Parade.
div.p: All regiments of the Egyptian Army, sta- tioned in Cairo, paraded in force on the Abbassia review ground yesterday morning at 7 a.m., together with the students of the Cadet School, and were inspected by the Sirdar.

div.head: Globe Trotting.
div.p: Mr. Joseph Gerard, the French globe-trotter, set out this morning from Alexandria at mid- day to continue his walk to San Francisco. Mr. Gerard is accompanied by Mr. Georges Mathieu, a Frenchman whom he met at Tunis on his last walking tour. We wish the couple a bon voyage.

div.head: Accidents.
div.p: A youn gnative girl of the Saida Zenab quarter has been very seriously injuried by the fall of a stack of timber. Her injuries are so severe that at least 40 days medical treat- ment will be necessary. The death of a young native girl has occured at Esbet Mohammadi, owing to her spilling a saucepan full of boiling water on her body.

div.head: Khedivial Mail S.S> Co.
div.p: The Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company Limited has taken new offices in the New Central Building situated in the Boulevard de Ramleh and Rue Adib, and their passenger and freight department will be in the Central Avenue, which i sshortly to be opened by the removal of the French Post Office. The Company will move into the new premises on the 1st October.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: For the week ending 10th instant, 57 cases of bubonic plague were reported throughout Egypt, of which 6 in the Beba district ; 7 at Beni-Mazar ; 2 at Assiout ; 2 at Mellawi ; 2 at Deirout ; 2 at Abnoub ; 3 at About-Tig ; 26 at Esneh ; 6 at Kos and 1 in the Dessouk district. 880 cases of plague were dealt with during this year up to 10th instant, as against 351 during the corresponding period of 1906. The following cases have since been reported :-1 death at Alexandria, 1 case and 2 recoveries at Beba, 1 death in hospital at Beni-Mazar, 1 case at Mellawi. Leaving 38 patients still under treatment.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Hassan Pasha arrived at Alexandria last night from Cairo.
Sir Reginald Wingate, who arrived at Alexandria last night, was received in private audience by the Khedive this morning.

Saba Pasha, the retiring Postmaster General bade ao formal farewell his inorning to. the officials and employés of the General and Alex andria Post Offices, prior ta. his departure for Europe this afternoon. The) Pasha's kindness of heart'and thoughtful care for those ander his charge have greatly endeared him to all ranks in the Postal Administration, and the orcasidh was & sag. one for all those who,were privileged to bid him "God-speed."
From today's date Bortorn Bey assumes the Postmaster-Generalship of Egypt.
Sir Augustus Hemming, G.C.M.G., Gover nor of Jamaica from 1897, who died in Egypt in March last, has left estate valued at £6,861.
Coles Pasha, director-general of the Prisons Administration, has arrived in Alexandria from Cairo.
Judge Bateheller jx leaving for America to: morrow and will remain at' New York until August.
The Emperor of Russia lias conferred the Order of St. Stensilas on Hamway Bey, Adviser to the Russian Consular Court at Aloxandria.

div.head: MOSLEM NATIONALISM.
SHEIKH MUSHIR EL KEDWAI.
FAREWELL DINNER IN LONDON.
div.p: London, Thursday.

A farewell dinner was given last night to Sheikh Moshir el Kedwai, Secretary of the Pan-Islamic Society, at the Carlton Hotel. Lady Cromer wrote regretting that Lord Cromer's absence was enforced by the unsatis- factory state of his health. His lordship wished her to add that he recognised with pleasure that Indian Pan-Islamism 'proceeded on differ- ent lines to that of Egypt. The Sheikh said that it was his constant desire that the English should have friendly relations with the Mos- lems, and be the guide towards progress on modern lines for Moslem dominions. He im- pressed his co-religionists of Egypt and his Hindu brethren that the prosperity of a/nation depended less on territorial possessions than industrial and commercial advancement, Re- generation is impossible unless they and their countries progressed economically and financially in' commeree and industry.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
div.p: Almost every day witnesses depreciations in the value of both stable and unstable shares on the Bourse, and it is difficult to account for the panic which appears to have seized 'investors and speculators in Egypt and brought down their yaluestoaltogetherridiculous prices. The daily quotations of the official list of the Bourse must be very disturbing to our readers, but in the opinion of./the great majority the bottom has been almost reached and there should be a recovery before long. The most regtettable result of the foolish panic now pre- yailing is that it will east discredit on the country, and foreign countries will lose confidence in-the boasted prosperity of Egypt The present condition of affairs is absolutely unwarranted, shares being in some cases 50 7 below their real value, but we must trust that confidence will soon be restored.

Consequent''to the petition of the brokers to the Committee of the Bourse for the hours to be reduced, it was dé@fided that the Bourse | should only be open for half an hour a day (11 to 11.80 am.). During that time-this morniug there was considerable excitement. One of the leading banks tried to force liquida- tion of one 6f their clients, but. lond whist- ling and shouting rendered any transac- tion' impossible, and the half hour was passed away in a perfect hubbub of excite- ment: Of the most notable depreciations of to- day are the Cassa di Sconto from 121 to 115 frs, sellers, the Agrieulfura} Bank from 7{ to 7%, and the Credit Franco-Egyptian from 43 to 4%. National Banks lost another }, and Salt ahd Soda went from 18/3 to 17/9. There was little business done, however, as the time was passed away by the hubbub caused by the attempted: liquidation,

div.head: BREACH OF DISCIPLINE.
div.p: On Tuesday morning last a Council of Discipline held a meeting-in order to congider the conduct of Hassan el Salem, clerk in- the Irrigation Inspectors' Office, who, as already reported, offended against the rules, of that Administration and is charged with exceeding the limits of his duties by summoning, without authority, many hotables of Minieh moudirieh to'attend at the departure of Mr. J.P, Hopkins, on the occasion. of his"Boing on leave, The accused, while acknowledging thé trouth, of the charge, defended his action by pleading ignorance of the laws and further declared to have received instructions from: hia chief. If view of the fact that the acensed is a new member of the staff, the Council showed great leniency by deciding to order -his suspension for one montli only, with temporary cessation of salary.

div.head: WALKER AND MEIMARACHI.
A PECULIAR POSITION.
LONDON BOARD'S DISCOVERIES.
div.p: London, Thursday.

I understand from the London Board of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi_Ltd., that they have discovered that Mr. Carton' de Wiart and Mr. Constantine. Meimarachi, have lapsed their directorships under the articles of association of the company, owing to having transferred their shares to bearer warrants, and therefore are no longer on the "register of the company. They also state that the secretary- ship of Egypt was abolished some time ago.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive returned: from Mariout to Alexandria this morning, and granted private. audience to Sir Eldon Gorst, Saba Pasha and Ezzat Pasha at Ras-el-Tin Palacé.

div.head: MINISTERIAL STAFF REFORMS.
div.p: The report of the Commission, which, under the Presidency of Mr. P.W. Machell, Adviser to thé Ministry of Interior, recently met to consider the question ofthe Ministerial staff, has been presented and, if the version we have been privileged to peruse is correct, a step in the right direction. is likely to be the outcome of the Commission.

As might be expected the Commission has attacked the question at the root, the principal step being the criticism of the present sys- tem by which the Ministers move their quar- ters annually to Alexandria during the sum- mer season: as a matter of fact there is noth- ing to be said against this in itself. The fact that each Minister is accompanied by one or more secretaries is freely commented on and to the most superficial observer it is evident that the division of the staff must be extremely prejudicial to the work.of the departments concerned, not,to mention the increased;cor- respondence oe by the separation of the principals'from the centre of operations and the subsequent extra work entailed on the staff, and the passage of messengers bet- ween Cairo and Alexandria.

The Commission suggested that the Mi- nisters either transfer the whole staff from Cairo to Alexandria during the summer months or-remain altogether in the Capital. The latter course was?strongly recommended, An extens- ion of the-working hours is recommended by the Commission in order to keep pace with the increasing work.

div.head: CONTRACTS IN MOROCCO.
CONCESSIONS TO GERMANY.
DIPLOMATIC CORPS PROHIBITION.
div.p: London, Wednesday.

As prognosticated by my cable ot April 18, the protest of several European legations against the secret granting of contracts for various public works by. the Commissioner of the Sultan of Morocco to Germany has re- sulted in the Diplomatic Corps unanimously deciding to. inform the Maghzen_ that no contract on the lines laid down must be signed and that the works mast be discontinued.
Tangier, June 12.
The Diplomatic Corps -has unanimously resolved that a recent secret_contract between the Maghzen and a German firm could not be allowed. (Reuter)

div.head: NATIONAL PRINTING OFFICE.
div.p: To the editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,— We beg to forward'. you a copy of the petition we addressed to the Financial Adviser exposing our situation and the treatment of our Director. We request that you will be kind enough to assist us in this question by inserting this copy in your newspaper. We have the honour to be Sir,
Your Obedient Servants. : The Workmen of the Printing Office at Boulae.
Cairo, June 12, 1907.

Excellency :— We, the workmen of the Na- tional Printing office at Boulac, have the honour to bring to your kind' notice the follow- ing :— Our Director has established for us an Association with the 'object of creating a fund to provide for accidents etc. occuring to the members. This furid has been formed by the retention of 3% of our salaries, joined to an equal sum granted by the Ministry of Finance. Three years after its establishment; a loss of LE. 310 resnlted from the purchhse of shares of companies, which has been done without, the consent of any member of the Association. Fegring that the remaining sum,will be lost the members 'decided to dissolve the Associa- tion. A petition to the effect was signed and a copy-of'same presented to the Direbtor with the indicatiow that the original js kept with Mr. Laurino, the Chief of the European work- men, and is ready to be presented when re- quired. But. the Director refused to give any answer to our petition, though our demand is only the application of Art. 38 of the regula- tions of the Association, approved by the Ministty*of Finance-by their decision of Novem- ber 22nd 1903, The Article states :
"The Association will be dissolved for 'any of the following reasons :
"1. Troubles oceurring in the Printing Office by the Administration of the Association.
"2. Dissentions among members
"3. Decision of the General Assembly of the Association.
"4, Considerable decrease of the members."

All these conditions have ,béen fulfilled, troubles and dissentions occurred, the General Assembly decided and the petitioners were more than 3/4 of all the workmen; in other words the whole staff 'except the recent work- men. In spite of all this, the Association 'was not dissolved.

There fs nothing in the regulations which makes membetship obligatory : no the contrary, it is understood that: members of the Associa- tion are "not entitled to any gratification or increase4 But the Director has been acting in a despotic manner inthis respect towards the employés. To give an example : oné of our number, Mr. Chupin, who has not joined the Association during the last 3 years, was officially notified by the Director that no gratification or increase will be' granted to him until he joins the Association, It was for this reason that all his companions were increased and promoted, while he was. neglected in spite of his being the eldest and most capable,

Seeing that the Director does not approve of dissolving the Association, and that he has been displeased from petitioners, they re- quested the modification of Articles 17 and 22 regarding the employment of the fund and the manner of granting indemnities to members dismissed--for economy etc, so that these articles become as those of the regulations in the Association of other administrations. The old workmen of thé Printing Office are tho- ronghly acquainted with their work, haying practised the same operations for years. But they are not promoted. French workmen froin Cairo and Paris are brought and appointed chiefs in spite of their ignorance and incapacity. Their only qualification for the high salaries they receive is their nationality,
We submit this petition trusting that you vil have pity on us and consider our situa- ion.
We have the honour to be Excellency, : Your obedient Servants
Sir Vinceyt Corperr Adviser, Ministry of Finance.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM.
div.p: The full text of the letter sent to the "Times" by the Society of Antiquaries (a sum- mary. of which was.cabled by our London cor- respondent, and appeared in our issue of the 6th) with regard to the steps to be. taken by the Egyptian. Government to preserve the archeological remains in the Nile Valley which may be affected by. the raising of the Nile Dan, is as follows :—

The proposal of the Egyptian. Government to raise the dam at Assuan by 23ft., and the consequent submergence of a vast area of country full of archeological remains, 'seem: to the Society of Antiquaries a step that might deserve more consideration than it had received, from the side of archeology. I was, therefore, instructed' by the society to: inquire of Lord Cromer whether somé other less' destructive means could not "be found that would confer the same benefits on the country. The answer, in the negative,.is given in the despatch from Lord Cromef printed in 'The Times" of April 23: While the Society of Antiquaries cannot but regret that such is the case, we feel that thé, measures that are to be taken by the Egyp- tian| Government to survey and record the antiquities threatened, have not been' brought prominently enough before the. public. I am, therefore, requested to forward a copy of a report received by the society from its represen- tative in Egypt, Mr. Somers Clarke, containing a brief account of the action to be taken in this respect, upon which the Egyptian Govern: ment is prepared to spend no less'a 8um_ than L.E. 60,000.
Your obedient servant, Cuaaves H. Reap, Secretary. Soc, Antiq. Lond., Burlington House; Piccadilly, W., June 1.
The submersion of parts of the Nile Valley and the measures to be taken by the Egyptian Government to minimize the evil :—

In January last I wrote from Egypt suggest- ing that the Society of Antiquaries should formulate a resolution and communicate it to the Egyptian Government in relation to the destruction which would overwhelm the anti- quities in Nubia if th dam at Assuan be raised 23ft above the present level ; and to the undertaking which the Egyptian Govern- ment ahd given, that the said antiquities should receive every consideration that was possible.

It cannot fail to interest the Fellows of the society to know that our representations have not been in vain, and that the care already taken to maintain the remains o nthe Island of Philae is to be extended to those temples and other places of archaeological and archi- tectural interest which will be submerged when the enlarged reservoir is full.
In "The TImes" of April 23 some extracts were given from a Parliamentary paper, known as "Egypt, No. 2, Despatch from the Earl of Cromer respecting the water supply of Egypt."

In justice to the Government of t, it should be stated that these extracts do not by any means give an adequate account of the liberal and enlightened spirit in which the difficulties of the case are being met. Indeed, it might be supposed -that arotind Philw alone was the fresh work of investigation to be centred. As a matter of fact, in order to avoid, if possible, the submersion of the antiquities, all parts of the valley between Assuan on the north and Khartum on .the south Were care- fully examined by a commission, espec ally | appointed for that purpose ; the geological formation was studied, and the. conf rmation of the Valley observed with regard 'to the capacity (a) for the storage of a body of water, i) economy of construction, (¢) materials at hand for such construction, (d) safety

Haviog regard to the quantity of water that can be impounded with a wall of a 'given leat it is now proved that no place offers such conveniences as Asian. Not less than £14,000 were voted for the investigation and necessary survey.

That which especially interests us is° the following _qnestion—What. steps will the Egyptian Government take to examine, survey and to preserve, and, finally, to give to the world the results obtained? We must bear in nind that not only archwology and architecture will suffer ; but also ethnolo; , botany, and, indeed, nearly all kindred sciences.
The swamping of any part of the Nile Valley is, for us, its destruction.
'The survey of that part of the:yalley which will be submerged has, to a considerable axtent, been initiated during) the examination already deferred to,

An archaeological survey is to be taken in hand, no effort being spared to render this as complete and thorough as possible In this sarvey will be included all temple and town sites, cemeteries, and all other indications of ancient civilization, Plans of these will be prepared to a large scale,
Copies will be made of all inscripti whether on walls or rocks, beianine with those which will e - subniaeieel The ancient cemeteries, &c., will be excayat éverything will be recorded.
The temples and other ancient buildings that can possibly be affected by the increased level of the eae in the reunbiels "sill be underpinned, fortified, and at the same time measured and: drawn
Lastly, the result of all investigations will be published to the world.

The sustentation of the temples will be undertaken 'by the ent of 'Anteattion under M. Maspero. The rest ofthe work is placed in charge of in Lyons, R.E. Those who have the plasure of kfibwing this gentle- man are well aware of the le. method, care, and thoro which he brings to bear on every work he undertakes.

The organization of the great work is already begun. The Egyptian Government has voted LE 60,000 in order that it may be carried out in its integrity. We may be glad that the suggestion for pulling down and re-erecting on another site part of the ruins at Philae has not been entertained.

div.head: AEGYPTIACA
THE PYRAMID TEXTS.
div.p: By Joseph Offord.

Thoguh th eancient magical treatise known as the "Book for the Dead" has for half a century been the most celebrated of all the old Egyptian literature, it is well known that there was another very similar composition which rivalled it in importance, and, probably, at one period, in popularity. The "Book for the Dead" had the good fortune to be represented, now 70 years ago, by a very complete papyrus copy kept in the Turin museum, which attracted the attention of Lepsius and was edited by him. It this obtained an early notoriety, and has maintained its supremacy over since.

The other composition known as the "Pyramid Texts," was not published until it was found inscribed upon the intereior chambers of the smaller Sakkara pyramid one or more of which were entered just previous to Marriette's decease. A few chapters of the before known "Book for the Dead" were also witten therein, but the majority were those of the newly found work.

They were edited and translated by M. Maspero in the "Recueil de Travaux" and in his book "Trois Annees de FOuilles dans les Tombeaux de Thebes, et de Memphis." The chief collections are from the Pyramids of Pepi I and II, Ounas, and Teta. But specimens of the work were soon, once it was known, discovered upon other monuments. Notably the tomb of Hor-hot-pou, which is in the Cairo museum ; and the sarcophagus of Anknearan e- ferab in London. One o fthe alst essays of the famous Dr. Birch was a translation of rescensives of some of the "Pyramid text" chapters in papyri of the Roman period, proving their popularity among some portions of the priesthood to quite a late date. It was a significant fact that all these payri asserted that their writing were copies of extrememly ancient ones found inscribed upon leathern rolls, always stated by the Egyptians to have been their primitive writing material, before papyri were invented.

It would seem that in some provinces of Egypt the Pyramid texts were for centuries ifnored,or forgotten, and only reused for funerary vase mecums for the dead, when rediscov- ered, probably by the rifling of some sepul- chre, engrossed upon old leathern scrolls.

But every year new discoveries prove that, though not so favoured in estimation as the "Book for the Dead," yet the Pyramid texts were known and rewritten, many of them are upon the coffin of Quees Hashepu for isntance, and others may be found in all the publications of Egyptian texts in recent years.

Last year however some gaps in the history of their utilisation were filled up. Mr. Garstang in his excavation , at Beni-Hassan, disinterred three sarcophagi whcih gave editions of quite 80 chapters of the work, and these new speci- mens contained interesting vairants and addi- tions to the copies in the pyramids.

Moreover Beni Hassan is in the XVI Nome, or province of ancient Egypt, and this is the first time any of these texts had been found in its district. This fact may not amount to much because the sarcophagi may have been decorated elsewhere. Again M. Barsanti in a tomb excavated by him close to the pyramud of Ounas found a series of "Pyramid texts" therein, dating from the Persian period;i.e. the 5th century B.C;and some also upon a coffin from another sepulchre.

Among the inscriptins upon the Grstand sarcophagi are several new chapters. Which may subsequently be found to belong to the "Book for the Dead" or to the Pyramid texts. One of these is entitled the "Chapter to pre- vent being destroyed in the Necropolis" the other "Describes the ladder which permits the defunct to ascend to heaven" We shall be better able to appreciate both these two ancient works when M. Lacau publishes all their texts upon sarcophagi in the Cairo museum. The numerous duplicates will enable lacunae to be filled up, scribal errors corected, and true variants compared, and then some real progress with the translation of this most difficult literature can be made.

Meanwhile, however, there is a third series of similar writings known as "Supplementary chapters to the Book for the Dead" whcih are augmenting with uncomfortable rapdity. herr G. Moller has just edited several such from'Hieratic papyri at Berlin. The chapter is called "that for ensuing the defunct shall he ewel-comed with joy in the world to come" another "To so bandage the body that no evil geni in the nether world can unroll him and no one devour him". One chapter that for "en-suring warmth beneath the head of the deceas-ed" is partly old, andpartly new. The previously known portion is that found upon the litttle payrus head pads known as Hypocephali-up on which the mummy's head rested. But thi schapter is in the new papyri stated to ahve been discovered in the cemetery under the neck of Rameses II.

This ay be a falsehood to increase its sup- posed value, or it may be, that when all the royal mummies were hurriedly bundled into the one tomb at the valley of the kinds the Hypocephalus of Rameses II was found, and kept by the priest as a good specimen of the text.
(1) Mr. Mond found extracts from both the "Pyramid Texts' and the "Book fo rthe Dead" in the tomb of Min-nekht at Thebes:see the excellent photographs in the Annales du Service des Antiquites 1905.

(2) The manner in whcih these old Egyptian concepts became part of the religious idea of later ties is well illustrated by this. In a worl entitled "The Glories of Mary" by S. Alfonso Lignori, reviewed by a "Catho- lic Priest" Dublin 1833, it is related that Brother Leo, once saw in a vision two ladders, one of them white:at its summit he saw the Virgin Mary. He saw that some who twice attempted to ascend the red ladder fell back. They were then exhorted to ascend the white ladder. The blessed Virgin astretched out her hand to them and they securely ascended to Paradise.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Mercredi 12 Juin 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres a baissé hier de 1/8. 35/8 pour cent. Aa Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a haussé ae 484. L'Unifiée est restée invariée & 00 t74> La National Bank a perdu 1/4 a 21 1 @E Agricole 1/8 48 1/8. La Daira Sanieh est Géinbiirée incbangée 414 7,8, de marie que WB Delta Light 49 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit,Foncier Bgyptien a rétro- gradé de 4 francs A70}et la Banque d'Athénes de 1 frahe 4 126.

On sait qu'il est depuis quelque temps question de reduire, pour la saison d'ete, la duree des seances des Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie. On a propose d'ouvrir a 10 h.30 ou a 11 h et de fermer a 11 h. 30 ou a midi. Aucune resolution definitive n'a ete encore prise a ce suject.

En attendant, hier, a la cloture de la Bourse d'Alexandrie, le voeu a ete emis que les seances soient reduites a une heure par jour, ou bien qu'elles soient supprimees pour un certain laps de temps...
Il est douteux que la seconde proposition puisse etre prise au serieux, a moins qu'on ne s'en rapporte au Syndicat pour etablir les prix des valeaurs pendant la saison morte.
Nous detachons d'une correspondance de Londres, en date du 5 Juin, le passage sui- vant :

" Le "Statist" compare les cours actuels des Consolidés anglais avec ceux cotés il ya 9 ou 10 ans et constate qu'il y a une'baisse d'en- viron 30 points. Il ya évidemment lieu di tenir compte de la réduction du taux d'inté mais, tout 'bien considéré, il y a encore une forte baisse. "Lorsque les Banques ramentrent les cours des Consdlidés 4 85 au bilan, tout le monde avait cru qu'elles avaient pris d'am- ples'précautions pour T'avenir. Pourtant, les 'Consolidés viennent de s'établir au-dessous de ce chiffre. Il ne faut donc pas se montrer sur- pris. si les'porteurs sont désappointés et se considérent maintenant comme beaucoup plus pauyres qiil ya dix" ans. Cet état d'esprit est méme ceqnse de l'arrét momentané des pla- cements.

" Le "Statist" ajoute que, pour parer a cet état de choses, le gouvernement prend des mesures pour r¢habiliter le crédit du pays. Cette arinée,en effet, le fonds damortissement représentera environ quinze millions de livrés sterling. Ces rachats feront disparattre le flot- tant et produiront certainement un mouve- ment graduel de hausse qui, en un. certain laps de temps, 'permettra anx Consdlidés de s¢ rapprocher du pair, "
Shivant des informations de Bruxelles, M.J Joannidés a été désigné pour remplacer M. A Heyndricks dans Ie conseil d' de la Société anonyme de la Brasserie des Pyramides.
Cette homihation sera soumise'a l'approba- tion 'de Padséitiblée' 'générale extfwordfndire des actionnaires convoquée 4 Bruxelles pour le 17 Juin courant.

Les journanx de Londres annoncent l'enre- gisrement, a la date du 28 Mai dernier, d'une nouvelle Societe sous la denomination de " Omnium Financier d"egypte. " L'objet de la Compagnie est de s'occuper d'affaires de Bourse, de banque, de concessions, et.

div.head:
FRENCH WINE BILLS.
THE MUNICIPAL RESIGNATIONS.

div.p: In the Chamber of Deputies the Wine Bills oceupied the whole Way, Continued resigna- tions of Southern' Municipalities are taking place, leading to municipal ¢haos, also render- ing marriages impossible. (Reuter)
The wine-growars' crisis is most serious. Municipalities have now resigned. Infantry at Montpellier hissed the command to suppress disorders. Mutiny reigned in the barracks.( R.)

The Tibunal has given judgment in. the attempted assassination case. Nackens, Mata, and Tbaria have been condemned to nine-years" imprisonment, Ferrer and the other accused have been-acquitted. (Havas)
An extraordinary sitting of Parliament with closed doors bas taken place. It "is stated that much misunderstanding between the Cabinet and Parliament has been removed, (Reuter)
According to news "received from, Askabad General Ulyanine, director. of 'the "Central 'Asian Railway, has been murdered there. (R.)

div.head:
AMERICAN AND JAPAN.
MR. TAFT'S REMARK.

div.p: Mr. Root has positively refused to make a statement regarding the Japanese situation. His refusal is based solely on his unwillingness to notice the alarmist'ramours.
Mr. Taft, in the course of an interview at Milwaukee, said : "Yon 'may rest assured the there will be no war with Japan." (Reuter)

div.head:
OBITUARY.
GENERAL SIR A. E. ELLIS.

div.p: General Sir A. E. Ellis, a member of the King's suite, died suddenly during a gala performance at Covent Garden in honour of the King and Queen of Denmark., (Renter)
A matinons regiment at Narbonne has been transferred elsewhere. (Reuter)
'The Senate has approved the proposal for the national féte on Jnly 4, the centenary/ of Guribaldi's birthday, (Havas)
Havas' Agency contradicts from a Russian source the report that M. Nelidoff will take the initiative at the Hagiie of the declaration of limitation of armaments. (Havas)
Bank thieves on being pursued killed two Police agents, a passer by, and a soldier. (2/.)
The Tsar has ratified the Cabinet's refusal to giant a concession for the Behring Straits railway and tunnel. This is an official correc- tion of the telegram of 10th instant. (Reuter)
South Africans beat Middlesex by 278 runs,
Sussex beat Derbyshire by 8 wickets,
The following matches have been abandoned, Yorkshire vy. Surrey, Warwickshire y. Lan- eashire, and Gloucestershire v. Northampton: shire. (Reuter)

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: There continues to be a very limited enquiry for Egyptians on the spot ; quotations however, in sympathy with: Futures, are raised 3/16 pr. Ib.
In Futures a fair business has been done, and the following are the closing prices — June 10.24 Sep. 10.23 Dec. 10.13 Mar. 10.10 July10.24 Oct. 10.22 Jan. 10.10 Aug. 10.24 Nov. 10.20 Feb. 10.10

American Futures. The Market this week has been active with frequent sharp fluctua tions, but the tendency has again been to higher values, and to-day's closing values are 153 @ 174 points higher for the Old Crop, and 5 @ 11 points higher for the New Crop posi- tions, than those of last Thursday.
The Bureau Report, although somewhat better than the forecasts, did not cause much set-back.

Later private information reporting-extre- mely/bad_weather conilitions completely demol- ished the Bureau Report, and another wave of speculative baying manipulation and and Bear covering' has carried prices higher than at any tinfe this season.

That the Crop has had an exceedingly unfor- tunate start and it is much later than osual in consequence, and therefore more éxposed to subsequent vicissitudes, there can be little doubt, but we cannot help thinking that there is considerable exaggeration due to the wide- spread "Bull" fever in the American markets and thronghont the South.
P.S# The Market fell back 7 @. 9 points late this afternoon upon cable reports of better weather having set in.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market.

During the latter part of the week the money market has been very firm, and the supply has been no, more than sufficient to meet the very brisk demand. which has been pre- valent. Reports from the country show that there has been an active call for 'cash, which has, of course, helped: to. redite "the matket supplies. In some cases yesterday as much as 4 per cent. was paid for da} to-day accomoda- tion, while the open market rate improved to 34 per centaThe discounting of July bills at the Bank afforded some ease in the afternoon, although the higher rates were maintained.

To-day there has again heen a good demand for money in Lombard Street, and day ad- vances have realised 341-3 per cent. weekly fixtures at 34 per cent. The open market for discounts is firm on the prospect of further exports of gold for abroad, and three months bills are quoted at 38 per cent.

This week the amount of bar gold due from the Cape and India was less than' half a million, the greater portion of which went to Paris.
The price of bar gold shows a slight advance on the week, being now quoted 77/10$ per ounce, as against 77/104 last Friday.
Silver is plentiful, and the quotation has receded slightly to 80, 13/16 per ounce.

This week's Bank return shows a consider: able shrinkage in the return. 'The withdrawals of gold for export amounted to £477,000, and as only £15,000 was returned from circulation and £221,000 in notes was withd the reserve is lower by £683,000, at £24,181,047. 'The proportion to liabilfties is 46.9 per cent Last year the reserve stood at £23,025,221 and the proportion at 44 3%.
The Stock Markets.

The past week has been 'a somewhat. un- settling one on the Stock Exchange. Failures and rumours of failures haye been predo-ninant, and although some of the reports of difficulties in various quarters have not been justified by subseqnent events, the market has had suffi- cient cause for uneasiness, 'The two failures which we reported last week were followed on Saturday by the hammering of another broker, and this week began with the announcement of the tragic death of the member in question at his country house»on Saturday: evening. Then came the failures of a Glasgow firm and a Paris operator, the latter involving liabilities of no less than £400,000.
These adverse influences, and the cobséquent liquidation of the accounts, have kept the stock markets in a state of nervousness, which is in no way lessened by the near approach of the account.
Yesterday there was some improvement in the tone as the result of a revivalin Aimericans, but this was somewhat offset by the slump in Consols.
This morning the old firm of Messrs. Star- key, Leveson, and Cooke have been declared défaulters, but this has not had a very serious effect, markets being quiet and featureless. Consols,
Consols.

The market for gilt-edged stocks has again been affected by heavy liquidation, which, added to the hardening of discount rates, yesterday cansed Consols to suffer a further slump, the closing prices showing a decline of 3/16 for cash and account, at 83, 11/16 and 83 respectively. The quotation for the account was thus 14 below the lowest figure touched, during 1906. Tonight Consols leave off at 83 9/16 and 83.
At their' present prices Consols produce, practically 3 per cent.
Foreign Bonds.

A feature of the Foreign market during the latter part of the week has been the weakness of Russians bonds; partly. due to the reported mutiny of a crack cavalry regiment at Tsarskoe Selo. The Five per cents. were put down to but when it was known that, contrary to expectations, Paris was a firm point, the market became more confident, and the quota- tién hardened to 82 buyers, a net loss on the day of }. The Fours shed a sifnilar amount to 73}, The only change in Japanese stocks yesterday was/i decline of 4 in the Second Series. of Fours to 863.
To-day Russians are unchanged, but Japan- ese have been offered, and close to lower.
Home Rails.

Shares in this section are irregular, and business is on a small scale. The week-com- menced witha further heavy slump in Brigh- ton issues, the Ordinary and Deferred being quoted 2 points lower on Monday night, The Deferred rallied to an appreciable extent on Tuesday, and recovered 1} to 83}. Yesterday Brighton Deferred were again better at 84.

Chatham Second Preference had a severe fall yesterday owing to the liquidation of a quintity-of-stock, The price at the opening was 48, butydrbpped to 42 before a buyer was found, thé only marking being 40/ South Eastern Deferred, moving in sympathy with Chathams, shed } to 36}, and the Preference 1 to 110. Great Easterns were firm at an advance of 1 point, at 103, and Metropolitan 'gained $ to 70}.
Home Rails have receded today, the only exceptions being Great Easterns, who have advanced }, and Chatham Second Preference, which have recovered 1/2.
Americans.

The unfayourable course of events in Wall Street has been an adverse influence in the American railway market, and the tone for the most part has been dull. During yesterday afternoon, however, a welcome improvement was noticeable, and prices benefitted in most cases, Unions, which had been as low as 134, Jumped.to 136}, and Southern Pacific register- edan advance Of 1} at 774. Aitchison and Steel Common were a full point above the ldwest quotations.
Americans have been irregular to-day. Read- ings and Uniotis have received attention but quotations for these show little change.
Egyptians.

'The Egyptian market is almost lifeless, and prices are quite nothinal. There appears to be little recovery in shares, and as soon as quota tions show a tendency to go better, there is a fresh burst of selling from Egypt.. The shares that have been taken at these low levels, have, however, gone into strong hands, andthis must have a goodeffect in the long run. National Bank of Egypt, after remaining round,about 23 for most of the week, have relapsed to 224, but seem firm at this figure. Agricultural Bank are down again to $}, andthe 4% Preference have changed hands"at 9,7/16 and 93.

Delta Preference Bearer have been dealt in up to 10}, at_which/price a few shares were disposed of, but last night left off at 9 7/8, with small buyers about at 9 3/4, They are to-night 93-10. Delta Land and Investment are 2 -1/4. Egyptian Estates are only 1,5/16, and the

Deferred have been sellers at 10. They close 8-10.

Egyptian Markets are quoted 1}-5/16, aud Salt and Soda {-1 nominal. . Daira are easier and without much market at 148-4. Land Bank are 73-8, and Union Foneieye 43-54, but there is no business doing in these shares,
Khedivial Mail Ordinary are offered at 26s. 6d., without response, The market for Comp- toir Financier is' practically dead, and these shares are now about 34-4.
Mining.

Althongh it cannot be said that there is any appreciable revival of interest in mining shares, it is a matter for satisfaction that the market has maintained a fairly cheerful tone through- out the depression Which has been so prevalent in most sections, and this is a good omen for the future.

The labour problem continues to occupy a prominent place in the minds of those interest- ed in the mining industry, From the replies of ministers in the House of Commons it is quite clear that it is the intention to push for- wart the yepatriation of the Chinese; and until a sufficiency of native labour to take their places is assured, ipining shares must inevitably remain under a clond.
This week prices.have been well maintained, and the changes are slight. Rand Mines are now quoted 5§ and East Rands 43.
'There is absolutely nothing, doing in the Egyptian mining shares. Nile Valleys remain at the low price of 1/-s. and Egyptian Mines Exploration at 1/9.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
A V I S
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de VEtat a 'honheur de porter 4 la connaissance da Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au vingt juin prochain, 4 midi au plus tard, des offres pour la fourniture de balais en "Samar," soit 10,000 (dix-mille) emmanchés et 3,000 (trois-mille) sans manches. Des échantillons devront étre soumis en' inéme temps que les offres. La li- vraison sera faite franco dans les Magasins de VAdministration 4 Gabbary (Alexandrie). Les Conditions Générales de cette fourniture peu- yént' @tre consultées au Bureau Central' du Service des Magasins 4 Boulac (Caire), et aux Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) 'tous les jours de neaf heures du matin a une heure p-m. les: Dimanches et jours fériés exceptés.

Un quart de la quantité des balais emman- chés est. 4 livrer immédiatement; un quart de la quantité totale des balais emmanchés et de ceux sans manches est a livrer dans deux mois et le regte sera livré quatre mois aprés la commande.

Pour étre admis a concourir, le soumission- naire tlevra verser, au préalable, a la Caisse de l'Administration, titre de dép6t provi- soil ne somme dé L.E. 20 (livres Egyptien- nes vingt). Le soumissionnairé déclaré adjudi- cataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'd concurrence du 10 % (dix pour cent) du mon- tant de l'offre agréée.

Les offres' devront étre accompagnées d'une feuille' de papier timbré de trente millitmes ainsi que du regu constatant le versement du cautionnement prdlfgoire susvisé. Elles seront adress¢es par la Poste sous pli recom- mandé a:
Monsieur le Directeur Général des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat
Le Caire.
et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante : "Offre pour Fourni- ture de Balais."
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accep- ter loffre la plus basse, ni 4 donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 30 Mai 1907. 30406-2-1

div.head: Alexandria Water Company Limited.
PAIEMENT DE DIVIDENDE.
div.p: Messjeurs les actionnaires sont informés qu'un Dividende de huit shellings' et quatre pence par action de £5 est payable le 15 Juin 1907 en échange da Coupon No. 37, 4 l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank Ltd. '4 Alexandrie, on chez Messrs. Barclay & Company Ltd. Pall Mall East a Londres.
Par ordre du Conseil d' Administration.
HR. C. Braapey.
Directeur.
Alexandrie, le 12.Jain 1907. 80470-4-2

div.head: H. DE VRIES AND BOUTIGNY LTD.
APPELS DE FONDS.
div.p: Le Conseil d'Administration a l'honneur d'informer MM. les actionnaires qu'il a ete decide de faire l'appel du 3me versement (5/- par action) le 1er Juillet 1907, et celui du 4me et dernier versemeat (5/-) le 1er Septembre 1907.
Les versements devront etre effectues aux guichets de H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd., rue Kasr-el-Nil, au Caire.
Il est rappele qu'aux termes de l'article 18 des Statuts toute somme non payee le jour de son exigibilite porte interet de plein droit en faveur de la Societe au taux de 9% l'an.
Le Caire, 11 Juin 1907.
Par ordre
du Conseil d'Administration,
E.W. Tester
30472-3-2 Secretaire.
